>
[Monkey's Fist](/Weapons.aspx?ID=130)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Finesse" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=179" />
<trait label="Monk" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=112" />
<trait label="Nonlethal" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=188" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Pathfinder #157: Devil at the Dreaming Palace](/Sources.aspx?ID=45) pg. 78</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 1 sp

**Damage** 1d6 B

**Bulk** —
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Hands** 1

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Category** Martial

**Group** [Flail](/WeaponGroups.aspx?ID=7)
</row>

</column>

---

Also called a “slungshot,” the monkey's fist is a short length of rope ending in a thick knot wrapped around a metal weight. You can tie the loose end of a monkey's fist to your wrist; if you are [Disarmed](/Actions.aspx?ID=41), the weapon remains secured to your wrist rather than falling to the ground, though you must use an Interact action to grip it before using it again. A monkey's fist is a martial melee weapon.

<title level="2">Critical Specialization Effects</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 283 <sup>4.0</sup></row>

Certain feats, class features, weapon runes, and other effects can grant you additional benefits when you make a Strike with certain weapons and get a critical success. This is called a critical specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which weapon group your weapon belongs to, as listed below. You can always decide not to add the critical specialization effect of your weapon.

[Click here for the full rules on Critical Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=235).
